Setting up Jekyll for Blogging - Part 2

Posts of this series:
  • Installing Jekyll
  • Creating the template
  • Final Changes

This is the second part of the series. We'll be creating the template from ground up and generating the website with all the necessary things. By the end of this post, we'll have a working website to show off.

Sections:

  1. Important Commands
  2. File Structure
  3. Create the Basic Template
  4. Divide and Rule
  5. Creating Pages
  6. Post Loops
  7. Pagination
  8. One Final Hack
  9. Conclusion
Update

The new version of Jekyll uses slightly different commands. I've updated the new commands on the appropriate places.

Once you are done installing Jekyll on your system, you will need to worry a little about a couple of commands you have to learn to apply in the terminal. Yes! The terminal! The arch enemy of most designers. But if you love the terminal, then welcome to my club!

Important Commands:

jekyll build           #compiles your templates and posts into html files

jekyll build --watch            #automatically builds your static files on updation of posts

jekyll server --watch   #automatically builds your static files and hosts it on a local server, localhost:4000

That's all the commands you will need for now.

File Structure

Jekyll has a specific file structure you must follow. Even though you'll find that a number of other additions may be done, for the sake of ease, I'll include only the ones we'll be using now, namely, _layouts, _includes, _site and _posts.

Why do we use '_' in the file and directory names? This isn't some vodoo required by Jekyll. The '_' is added to every file or directry name you don't want to be added in your website. However the site will be generated from the contents of the '_' prepended files.

You might have noticed a file named _config.yml. This is the configuration file for the website we'll be creating. The content of this _config.yml file is:

name: "LinWeb"
description: "This is the offcial blog of LinWeb - the brainchild of Sumit"

url: "http://blog.linweb.tk"

paginate: 10

markdown: rdiscount
permalink: pretty
pygments: true

This is YAML front matter. I'll explain it in brief.

  • name: This is to be followed by the name of your website. In my case it's LinWeb. This is the title of your site.

  • description: Ever seen the meta description tag? Yes, we'll use this there.

  • url: Self describing. But if it's a subdirectory where you'll be placing your website in, you must make sure, you type the right url where you'll be placing the generated site.

  • markdown: I am using RDiscount as the Markdown engine.

  • paginate: Usually you won't find hundreds and thousands of posts listed in a single home page. They are divided over multiple pages. This is called pagination. We have set a limit of 10 posts per page.

  • permalinks: If you have used pretty links in wordpress or any other CMS, you'll know what it it. For those who don't, permalinks is short name for permanent links. The various posts you'll be creating will be stored in a structured manner as defined by you in the configuration.

  • pygments: As mentioned in Part-1, Pygments is a syntax highlighter. I am using it because I'll post code snippets in my posts. You may not. So, there's no reason why you should use it.

This was only a couple of YAML configuration settings, you will need. I have only scratched the surface. You'll find an extensive list at the wiki of Jekyll. You can change the entire file structure using custom configuration. However, I like to keep things simple.

Creating the Basic Template

Before we begin, I must mention that the templates in Jekyll rely on Liquid tags heavily. Don't worry about learning a whole different language. It's preety easy to use. If you can code in HTML and CSS, then you can use Liquid markups too.

There are two types of markup in Liquid:

  • Output markup which may or may not resolve to text

  • Tag markup which cannot resolve to text

Liquid tags are used with basically the same idea as using a CMS where we create pages with the same template but with different content.

Let's create a HTML file first in the _layouts folder.

I love using the Foundation framework for quickly coming up with a responsive design. I'll use the same here. I am hoping you are familiar with SASS. Even if you are not, no worries, I'll post a CSS file for you.

We have created a project inside _layouts folder. We'll move the stylesheets and javascripts, folders out to the root directory. Why? We already know that all the files and folders in the root directory without the '_' prepended in their names are automatically added to the final build. We definitely want our stylesheets and javascripts folders to be added. However, we want the index.html file to become our template. So, we'll keep it right where it is.

Now to make sure that the SASS files are compiled to CSS files at the right locations, we'll change the contents of config.rb to:

require 'zurb-foundation'
http_path = "/"
css_dir = "../stylesheets"
sass_dir = "sass"
images_dir = "../images"
javascripts_dir = "../javascripts"

output_style = :expanded
line_comments = false

Let us build the basic template. I am using my template for example as that would be the best way for me to explain. However, don't get messed up in the jargon of code. Just follow my lead.

Divide and Rule

Do you remember that we created a folder named _includes? That is the prime benefactor whenever we are going to create templates. If you have worked with any CMS themes or even PHP, you'll know how we include different markup files to create a template or sometimes various templates.

In other words, suppose you have a main page that shows all the posts. And a post page that includes a Comment section and maybe a sidebar. But those are not included in the main page. The rest of the parts are same. So, do we create two separate templates rewriting the same code? Of course not! We'll reuse the same markup to create separate templates and keep on adding or removing whatever we need or don't need.

Using _includes is simple. I needed a <div> for including the comments section. The rest of the parts were same. So, here's how divided my markup into two files: header.html and footer.html.

For including the comments section in the post template, I created another file (even though I could have easily created it from the existing footer.html): footerpost.html

Did you notice that I sliced the big file into two right at the point where we were supposed to enter our content (that comment I asked you to focus on) ?

Now we'll save all these files into _includes directory.

Once, we are done with the previous step, we can delete the index.html we created in the _layouts directory. Because we'll create two different templates now.

Let's create two files: default.html and post.html

We'll use default.html for creating pages and post.html for creating posts.

default.html
  

{% include header.html %}

{{ content }}

{% include footer.html %}
post.html
  

{% include header.html %}

{{ content }}

{% include footerpost.html %}

Creating Pages and Posts

Now that we have created the templates, we can start creating pages for our website. Let's create a About page first.

---
layout: default
title: Contact Me
tags: contact,linweb
description: This is the Contact Page of LinWeb. If you have any queries or requests, contact the admin.
---

Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet, consectetur adipisicing elit, sed do eiusmod
tempor incididunt ut labore et dolore magna aliqua. Ut enim ad minim veniam,
quis nostrud exercitation ullamco laboris nisi ut aliquip ex ea commodo
consequat. Duis aute irure dolor in reprehenderit in voluptate velit esse
cillum dolore eu fugiat nulla pariatur. Excepteur sint occaecat cupidatat non
proident, sunt in culpa qui officia deserunt mollit anim id est laborum.

Save this file as about.html in your root directory, so that it is automatically included when Jekyll builds our website.

We can similarly create many other pages.

The main part about the above snippet is layout. We created two templates in _layouts directory. One was named default.html and the other post.html. We used default in layout in the YAML front matter. So, when Jekyll builds our website, it'll process this file and it's contents and based on the YAML front mater, the default.html layout will be used.

By now you can guess how we'll build the posts.

Yes! Using layout: post in the YAML front matter of the posts. However, we'll save the posts not as .html files but as .md (markdown) files in the _posts directory.

And one more thing. Save your posts with the name that follows the following format:

2013-03-28-my-first-post.md

I won't explain why. Try it on your own and you'll know why.

Hint: Remember the line permalinks: pretty

You can however change the way you can save your posts. But you should consult the wiki first to know how to.

But there's one problem with our home page. Our purpose was to build a blog. However, the main page still doesn't show a list of the posts. For that we need to learn a new concept.

Post Loops

Consider this code snippet:

{% for post in site.posts limit: 5 %}
    <li><a href="{{ post.url }}">{{ post.title }}</a></li>
{% endfor %}

There's a for loop in the above snippet. It works like any other programming language. Still I'll explain it for you.

The for loop goes through all the posts you have in your site, i.e., _posts directory, with a limit of 5 latest posts and creates a <li> tag with title of the post inside it and links to the post. SInce this is a loop, it recursively looks for the latest 5 posts till all the posts have been checked.

We'll use the same looping technique to create our home page which shows the list of all the blog posts. The updated home page will be:

index.html
---
title: Home
layout: default
tags: linweb,blog,linux,web,design
---
<div class='blog_excerpts'>
    {% for post in site.posts limit:10 %}
        <h3 class='post_title'>
            <a href="{{ post.url }}">{{ post.title }}</a>
        </h3>
        <h6 class='post_date'>{{ post.date |  date: "%d %B %Y"}}</h6>
    {% endfor %}
</div>

Now we are almost done. See the result by running in your terminal:

jekyll serve --watch

Browse to localhost:4000 and you'll be able to see your website.

As you can see, there's a Disqus comment box at the end of the posts you have created. Notice in the template I've removed the disqus_shortname. You must have one of your own to use disqus.

We can see our website is working. But somehow there's still a couple of finetuning jobs to do. Let's get on with it.

Pagination

I really didn't know how to make this work. I took help from a tutorial by Andrew Munsell.

If you have more than 10 posts, you'll notice that the latest 10 posts are listed on the home page and the others are lost in some other dimension! It's because you set limit: 10 in the loop excerpt above.

To me, this is a problem. We need pagination such that other posts are displayed on the next page, say, http://example.com/page/2.

So, we'll use the global variable : paginator

Remember we set paginator: 10 in the _config.yml file. So, all we need to do now is remove the limit: 10 we used in the snippet above and replace site.posts to paginator.posts.

Now we need to add the /page2 directory in our generated website folder. The paginator global variable has previous_page and next_page properties. We can now modify our index.html to:

---
title: Home
layout: default
tags: linweb,blog,linux,web,design
---
<div class='blog_excerpts'>
    {% for post in paginator.posts %}
        <h3 class='post_title'>
            <a href="{{ post.url }}">{{ post.title }}</a>
        </h3>
        <h6 class='post_date'>{{ post.date |  date: "%d %B %Y"}}</h6>
    {% endfor %}

    <div class='blog_pagination'>
        <ul class='inline-list'>
            {% if paginator.previous_page %}
              {% if paginator.previous_page == 1 %}
              <li><a href="/">Prev</a></li>
              {% else %}
              <li><a href="/page{{ paginator.previous_page }}">Prev</a></li>
              {% endif %}
            {% else %}
            <li><span class="disabled">Prev</span></li>
            {% endif %}
            {% if paginator.page == 1 %}
            <li><span class="active">1</span></li>
            {% else %}
            <li><a href="/">1</a></li>
            {% endif %}
            {% for count in (2..paginator.total_pages) %}
              {% if count == paginator.page %}
              <li><span class="active">{{ count }}</span></li>
              {% else %}
              <li><a href="/page{{ count }}">{{ count }}</a></li>
              {% endif %}
            {% endfor %}
            {% if paginator.next_page %}
            <li><a href="/page{{ paginator.next_page }}">Next</a></li>
            {% else %}
            <li><span class="disabled">Next</span></li>
            {% endif %}
          </ul>
    </div>
</div>

One Final Hack

I have to share this! Because I had quite a bit of trouble to solve this. You'll notice that all your posts are fully printed in the main page. Now some people may like it but as far as I know, most prefer the Read More link after an excerpt.

Liquid markup makes this possible. All you have to do is change your index.html to the following. Do notice the change I made.

---
title: Home
layout: default
tags: linweb,blog,linux,web,design
---
<div class='blog_excerpts'>
    {% for post in paginator.posts %}
        <h3 class='post_title'>
            <a href="{{ post.url }}">{{ post.title }}</a>
        </h3>
        <h6 class='post_date'>{{ post.date |  date: "%d %B %Y"}}</h6>
        <div class='post_excerpt'>{{ post.content | split: '<!-- more -->' | first }}
            <a href="{{ post.url }}">Read More...</a>
        </div>
    {% endfor %}

    <div class='blog_pagination'>
        <ul class='inline-list'>
            {% if paginator.previous_page %}
              {% if paginator.previous_page == 1 %}
              <li><a href="/">Prev</a></li>
              {% else %}
              <li><a href="/page{{ paginator.previous_page }}">Prev</a></li>
              {% endif %}
            {% else %}
            <li><span class="disabled">Prev</span></li>
            {% endif %}
            {% if paginator.page == 1 %}
            <li><span class="active">1</span></li>
            {% else %}
            <li><a href="/">1</a></li>
            {% endif %}
            {% for count in (2..paginator.total_pages) %}
              {% if count == paginator.page %}
              <li><span class="active">{{ count }}</span></li>
              {% else %}
              <li><a href="/page{{ count }}">{{ count }}</a></li>
              {% endif %}
            {% endfor %}
            {% if paginator.next_page %}
            <li><a href="/page{{ paginator.next_page }}">Next</a></li>
            {% else %}
            <li><span class="disabled">Next</span></li>
            {% endif %}
          </ul>
    </div>
</div>

Conclusion

We have successfully created a template for ourselves. Even though I haven't mentioned styling anywhere, it is an important part. Nobody will like your blog if it's plain ugly. So, I would suggest that you use the concepts you learned in this post or from elsewhere to build your own template from scratch.

Even though we have build the website, there's still a lot to cover. In next post, I'll be covering deployment of your newly built blog and customizing your server to make it super fast. I'll also throw in some SEO techniques. And we'll do some nifty little changes to our template.
